abstract: Helion Energy achieves plasma at a stunning 150 million degrees Celsius, well above the threshold to eventually generate stable fusion power.
title: Sam Altman‚Äôs fusion startup Helion Energy hits 150 million degree plasma temperature‚Äîa milestone that could bring first grid power in 2028

imageResources.title: Sam Altman‚Äôs fusion startup Helion Energy hits 150 million degree plasma temperature‚Äîa milestone that could bring first grid power in 2028
imageResources.caption: Helion Energy‚Äôs Polaris fusion energy prototype was built just outside Seattle.

body:
The Sam Altman‚Äìchaired Helion Energy fusion power developer announced a new milestone Feb. 13, achieving record plasma temperatures of 150 million degrees Celsius‚Äî10 times that of the sun‚Äôs core‚Äîas part of its immensely ambitious goal to bring power to the grid in Washington State by 2028.

Startup developers of fusion energy‚Äîthe so-called power of the stars in a jar‚Äîare racing to prove their technologies and bring clean, limitless electricity to the grid to meet the power needs of the AI boom. While Helion has the most aggressive timeline for first commercial power‚Äîunder contract for Microsoft data centers‚Äîskeptics have questioned Helion‚Äôs start date; its unique technological approach versus competitors; and its relative lack of scientific updates until now.

‚ÄúWhile interstitial milestones are really important to show that the technology works and you can get regulatory approval, at the end of the day, it‚Äôs about deploying power plants at scale to support the growing power needs,‚Äù Helion cofounder and CEO David Kirtley told Fortune.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre on schedule to still have first electrons to the grid in 2028. It is an aggressive milestone. It‚Äôs going to be hard,‚Äù Kirtley said. ‚ÄúPart of that is the progressive iteration and parallel development right now in Malaga, Washington.‚Äù

While the plasma heat achievement was set at Helion‚Äôs seventh-generation prototype, Polaris, in suburban Seattle, Helion already is building its 50-megawatt commercial power plant, Orion, 130 miles away in Malaga‚Äînear Microsoft‚Äôs growing data center campus. Helion is not yet assembling the fusion reactor, which requires additional engineering and design fine-tuning.

Developing multiple projects in parallel‚Äîincluding an assembly line manufacturing system‚Äîis key to Helion‚Äôs rapid pace and success, Kirtley said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs how we have been able to build seven generations of fusion systems and do it much quicker than anyone else in fusion. Core to the philosophy of how we operate is that rapid build, test, iterate, and build again.‚Äù

Whereas traditional nuclear fission energy creates power by splitting atoms, fusion uses heat to create energy by melding them together. In the simplest form, it fuses hydrogen found in water into an extremely hot, electrically charged state known as plasma to create helium‚Äîthe same process that powers the sun. When executed properly, the process triggers endless reactions to make energy for electricity. But stars rely on overwhelming gravitational pressure to force their fusion. Here on Earth, creating and containing the pressure needed to force the reaction in a consistent, controlled way remains an engineering challenge.

And because fusion reactors are so much smaller than stars, they need to produce heat in much hotter concentrations. The sun is about 15 million degrees Celsius at its core, or 27 million degrees Fahrenheit.

About 100 million degrees Celsius is considered the minimum threshold for sustained commercial fusion power, hence the enthusiasm over the new milestone.

Helion was founded in 2013, and Altman became chairman and a major financial backer in 2015‚Äîshortly before he cofounded OpenAI. Altman also became chair of the nuclear fission, small modular reactor (SMR) startup Oklo that same year. Other key Helion investors include LinkedIn cofounder Reid Hoffman and Facebook cofounder and current Asana CEO Dustin Moskovitz. Kirtley said Altman‚Äôs role is to focus on the long-term vision.

‚ÄúA question I get from Sam is, ‚ÄòHow do we move faster?‚Äô‚Äù Kirtley said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre already on an aggressive time frame. ‚ÄòHow do we move faster than that? How do we deploy power at scale quickly?‚Äô‚Äù

Unique fusion approach

Kirtley previously worked at NASA-backed MSNW on fusion-driven rocket technologies. He cofounded Helion with a dual focus of fusion power and fusion propulsion. The propulsion work helped Helion innovate its unique power approach, he said.

‚ÄúOne thing you learn about working in space and building systems to fly in space is you can‚Äôt waste anything. Every ounce of weight is critical; every watt of power is critical,‚Äù Kirtley said. ‚ÄúYou must be very efficient everywhere and all the time. If you take that same approach and apply it to fusion, all the physics requirements dramatically reduce.‚Äù

Most fusion technologies, as well as nuclear fission, are based on generating heat to power steam turbines, which produce the electricity. Helion‚Äôs technology captures the electricity during the fusion process‚Äîskipping the need for turbines.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs really the fundamental difference that we believe allows us to move much faster than other people,‚Äù Kirtley said. ‚ÄúThat shrinks the scale of the fusion system. It minimizes how hard it is to do.‚Äù

Helion‚Äôs fusion fuel combines deuterium from water with tritium. Helion was the first company licensed to use radioactive tritium as a fusion source. But the end goal is to use deuterium and helium-3, which Helion aims to produce by fusing the same deuterium atoms. Helium-3 allows the process to generate more electricity with less heat.

Arguably Helion‚Äôs chief fusion competition is Nvidia and Bill Gates‚Äìbacked Commonwealth Fusion Systems (CFS), which has deeper pockets but is taking a more conservative approach. Commonwealth leans on the most traditional fusion technology‚Äîhighly relative for a nascent industry that‚Äôs never generated electricity on the grid.

CFS is currently building its SPARC fusion prototype to come online next year. But that won‚Äôt provide power to the grid. If SPARC succeeds, CFS‚Äôs first commercial fusion plant, ARC, is slated to be built and to come online in the early 2030s just outside of Richmond, Va. If all goes as planned, the 400-megawatt plant‚Äîmuch more power than Helion‚Äôs Orion‚Äîwould produce enough electricity to service about 300,000 homes.

CFS leans on the so-called tokamak design‚Äîshortened from toroidal magnetic chamber‚Äîwhich relies on its powerful magnets. The technology essentially involves a massive, doughnut-shaped machine that traps the plasma in a high-temperature, superconducting magnetic field. But the process generates heat, not electricity.

Helion‚Äôs smaller, but faster approach uses magneto-inertial fusion. Theoretically, the plasmas collide in the fusion chamber and are compressed by magnets around the machine. That heats the plasma, initiating fusion reactions and resulting in a change in the plasma‚Äôs magnetic field. This change interacts with the magnets, increasing their magnetic field, and initiating a flow of new electricity through the coils.

The bottom line is it‚Äôs quite complicated, and there‚Äôs no guarantee of success for any of the fusion developers. But Kirtley said he‚Äôs confident fusion power can make a notable dent in the U.S. power grid within the next decade and keep growing from there.

‚ÄúIf all we do is build the world‚Äôs first fusion power plant, as a company, we failed,‚Äù Kirtley said. ‚ÄúOur goal is to deploy clean and safe baseload power to the world. That means building technologies in a way that is scalable, mass producible, and must be low cost so that the customer wants it.‚Äù

This story was originally featured on Fortune.com

**Helion Energy Achieves Fusion Milestone**  

üî• **Record Plasma Temperature**: Helion Energy reached **150 million ¬∞C**, **10√ó hotter than the sun‚Äôs core**, advancing toward its goal of delivering **grid power by 2028**.  

‚ö° **Innovative Fusion Approach**: Unlike traditional nuclear fission, Helion captures electricity **directly from fusion**, using **magneto-inertial fusion** and skipping turbines, enabling **faster deployment**.
